section.name: Frontend skin customization
section.p: The layout on the screen, the colors and formatting used, and things like the icons in place for the front-end are generally known as a skin. Customizing the application to give a different look is performed by applying a different skin. A different skin should not be used to create a different functional application. Functionality is added by incorporating another plugin in the packaged product. This in itself should not lead to having to apply a different skin.

The most obvious part of a skin is the cascading style sheet (CSS) file. The CSS file determines the default font sizes, spacing, etcetera to be used for all elements. Also part of the skin are icons in use by either CSS file (such as declaring a button or background image) or elsewhere.

There always needs to be a skin with the CSS file and icons to be used, a packaging project like the CMS needs to supply it. The default CMS skin is supplied in the project hippo-ecm-cms-skin. A skin itself is an add-on like others and can be combined with other skin plugins.

subsection.name: Create your own skin
subsection.p: You can create your own skin by creating a project with the same structure and content as the hippo-ecm-cms-skin project as supplied in cms/skin. You can also take the hippo-ecm-cms-skin WAR, rename it and modify it to your needs. This works because this add-on is just a collection of files, and building the WAR is just a packaging of the files. No actual compilation of sources is required.

The first thing to do when creating a copy of the skin project is to change the name of the artifact in the pom.xml (when building using Maven) and in the src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml (or WEB-INF/web.xml when modifying the resulting WAR). Do not use the same package name as the default. The resulting WAR should have a different name and different description in the WEB-INF/web.xml.
You can not change the context-root of the skin. All skin files in the final produced end-application are retrievale under the skin/ path.

subsection.name: What to customize

dl.dd: When creating your own skin you can modify the cascading style sheet in use, such as the src/main/webapp/style.css. In the packaged WAR this file is placed in the root of the WAR. The style.css is the primary style file in use, but there are others for specific screens, such as the login screen.
Icons in use are placed in the images directory. Just put any different icons in your own project when you want them different.

Web pages as served back to a browsing client are not single HTML files in the front-end. Rather than single files bound to a specific page requested, a web page is composed of HTML fragments.
Each item on a web-page is supplied by a piece of program code in the front-end. Together with this Java program code, a HTML fragment in given. These HTML fragments are merged into a single HTML file. These HTML fragment files are not defined on a per-page basis, but on the class of the item used. Therefore a change to the HTML file representing, for instance a kind of button, is reflected in all buttons of that kind used everywhere.
By being able to override the HTML for all items, you are able to further customize the layout of the pages.

subsection.p: To override HTML files, you need to identify which HTML fragment file you need to override. This depends on the add-on you are using and which frontend plugin delivers that particular HTML fragment.
Suppose an add-on in use defines an item which is a BreadCrumbPlugin. Next to the Java class implementing this item, there is an HTML fragment file:
subsection.source: `-- src `-- main `-- java `-- org `-- hippoecm `-- frontend `-- plugins `-- admin `-- breadcrumb |-- BreadCrumbPlugin.java `-- BreadCrumbPlugin.html
subsection.p: This is in the original add-on that supplies the item on the web-page. If you want to provide an override for this HTML fragment in your skin, then put this alternate BreadCrumbPlugin.html file in your skin project.

Within the skin project, the location of this HTML fragment should be src/main/webapp/org/hippoecm/frontend/plugins/admin/breadcrumb/BreadCrumbPlugin.html resulting in the final WAR project as file org/hippoecm/frontend/plugins/admin/breadcrumb/BreadCrumbPlugin.html.

In summary, the location of an overriding HTML fragment file should follow the same directory structure as the original HTML fragment file, but instead of the initial location src/main/java you should use src/main/webapp.

subsection.name: How to apply a skin
subsection.p: The end application is a packaging of the core system as well as multiple add-ons. These add-ons are either WAR or JARs which are merged or put together in an EAR. Please refer to the building section on how to compose your end application by adding add-ons to your application.
The default skin of Hippo CMS 7 is defined by the project that produces the hippo-ecm-cms-skin artifact. If you want to apply a different skin, replace this artifact with your own.

If you use an EAR target, this means simply replacing the hippo-ecm-cms-skin.war by another skin WAR target. If you use a merged WAR target, then you need to rebuild the end WAR with a different artifact dependency in the pom.xml. Replace the dependency to the hippo-ecm-cms-skin artifact by your own skin artifact.
